Graphical abstract Copper-exchanged SSZ-13 and SAPO-34 (Cu/CHA) zeolites catalysts have been commercially utilized for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx by NH3. Despite the significant advances in both fundamental research and industrial application have been made, the limited catalytic activity at low exhaust temperatures, the challenges of sulfur/alkali (alkaline) metal/phosphorus poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation have spurred the development of new generation NH3-SCR catalysts. This paper reviews the recent progress for Cu/CHA in regard to zeolite synthesis, the latest SCR reaction mechanisms, the poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms, more importantly, corresponding poisoning-resistant and protective strategies are also proposed, some issues that still need to be addressed are also highlighted. We hope to construct a linkage between next generation of catalysts and real-world applicable demands to meet the escalating emission regulations in the near future. Keywords NH3-SCR Cu/CHA Reaction mechanism Poisoning mechanism Hydrothermal stability 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx), mainly originating from the stationary sources and automobiles, bring about some alarming environmental issues such as greenhouse effects, photochemical smog, and PM2.5 [1]. The ever-increasingly stringent emission regulations have spurred continuous improvement of high-performance SCR (selective catalytic reduction) catalysts adapted to various harsh conditions. The history of science and technology development for deNOx from vehicle exhausts could be expediently divided into three ‘eras’ [2]. In the first ‘era’ between mid-1970’s and mid-1980’s, the most common exhaust catalyst, the three-way catalyst (TWC), was used in gasoline vehicles. TWCs reduced NOx best at the stoichiometric air/fuel ratio and under rich (excess fuel) conditions, nevertheless, their wide-spread application on so-called “lean-burn” has been limited by the inability to lower NOx level at high air/fuel ratios, which opened the prelude to the second ‘era’ as scientific and technical personnel committed themselves to explored alternative technologies that were appropriate for the deNOx under lean-burn conditions. The rapid improvement of metal-based zeolite SCR catalysts for diesel vehicles was by no mean accomplished at one stroke, which was inspired by the development of vanadium-based catalysts for NOx reduction in stationary sources (e.g., power stations, factories) [3]. In 1986, a milestone paper describing that Cu/ZSM-5 (medium-pore zeolite) facilitated the catalytic decomposition reaction of NO into N2 and O2 was reported by Iwamoto et al. [4]. However, metal-exchanged zeolites catalyzing NO decomposition was gradually abnegated as a choice owing to insufficient NOx conversion to meet practical requirements. Shortly thereafter, Cu- and Fe- exchanged ZSM-5 was widely investigated as an NH3-SCR catalyst in the early 1990s [5]. Disappointingly, it was found that ZSM-5 zeolite deactivated quickly owing to the poor hydrothermal stability [6]. For this reason, Cu- and Fe- exchanged beta (large-pore zeolite) were extensively studied for SCR catalysts because they revealed enhanced durability compared with ZSM-5 [7]. Still, beta zeolites could not retain their high activities under practical operating conditions. Due to the fairly large pore size and cages, the unburned hydrocarbon molecules were able to reside within the beta zeolite, the periodic high temperatures arising from the combustion of the hydrocarbons would severely degrade the zeolite structure [8]. Note that the catalysts used in exhaust treatment devices must meet the regulated durability requirements, in the terms of the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) standards: 150,000 miles for a light-duty vehicle and up to 435,000 miles for a heavy-duty vehicle [9]. Considering this, it seems likely that the exploration of small-pore zeolite hosts may exclude the passage of larger unburned hydrocarbons. In 2009, the Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, possessing outstanding NH3-SCR performance and better resistant to hydrocarbon poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation than medium-pore zeolites, were investigated by Bull et al. [10]. Soon afterwards, Fickel et al. [11] discovered that Cu/SAPO-34 shared similarities with Cu/SSZ-13 in catalytic performance and hydrothermal stability. These advantages enabled CHA (structure code for chabazite framework)-based catalysts to commercial applications for NOx reduction in 2010, which are now widely applied for urea SCR system in vehicle exhaust emission. In terms of a modern diesel exhaust aftertreatment system, several typical configurations are indispensable, including a diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC), a diesel particulate filter (DPF), a SCR unit, and an ammonia slip catalyst (ASC) [12,13]. Fig. 1 illustrates the different key components and corresponding functions [14]. Owing to the complexity and high cost of above aftertreatment systems, recently, integrating the DPF and the SCR into a single device has been proposed and studied by Martinovic et al., [15,16], which is called a SCR on Filter (SCRoF) device. The combination of SCR catalyst and soot oxidation catalyst has been demonstrated to be promising for simultaneous removal of NOx and soot on a single filter. In addition, the Lean NOx Traps (LNT) technology and SCR technology are both the most efficient in the removal of NOx from diesel exhaust. In order to increases the NOx conversion and the nitrogen selectivity, the coupling of LNT and SCR technologies has been also proposed, specifically, the formation of an NH3 slip during the lean phase in the LNT-catalyst could be stored in the SCR catalyst and, then, it would react with the unconverted NOx in the oxidant phase [17]. The commercial application of urea SCR system for deNOx under lean-burn conditions represents a period of great prosperity of the second ‘era’. While legislations on emission control are becoming more stringent worldwide, note that Internal Combustion Engines (ICE) will be around for at least the next several decades and fuel efficiency will be continually improved [9], hence, with the progress and implementation of upgraded engine technologies, engine-exhaust temperatures will sharply drop. In such a low temperature region, there are two problems that need to be solved in current system for diesel engines: (1) the inability to decompose urea prevents full exploitation of the SCR technology. (2) Cu- and Fe-exchanged zeolite are poorly active in reducing NOx. It brooks no delay to improve current technologies or to develop new technologies to overcome the limitations. These significant challenges have initiated a third ‘era’ in late 2012, which encourages scientists to explore new technologies. Over the past several years, some promising concepts called “AdSCR” (adsorption + selective catalytic reduction) [18] and “PNA-SCR” (passive NOx adsorber + selective catalytic reduction) [19,20] were proposed to alleviate this problem, which were dedicated to capture NOx, preferably NO, when urea could not decomposed (e.g., below 170 °C) and release them when a down-stream urea-SCR system became operational. PNA materials including Pd-containing CHA or MFI (structure code for mordenite framework inverted framework) appear more promising, however, challenges remain with complex trapping conditions (e.g., repeated cold starts, the presence of other exhaust species such as CO2, H2O, CO and hydrocarbons, sulfur poisoning and hydrothermal aging deactivation) [21–24]. Clearly, a lot of scientific research and engineering practice is required to do, especially in light of “The 150 °C Challenge”, which is aimed to identify new materials and aftertreatment approaches that offer the potential for 90 % conversion of emissions at low temperature (150 °C) [25]. Despite Cu/CHA catalysts have received extensive attention, more effort should be made to explore highly efficient, excellent poison-resistant and robust SCR catalysts. In this review, we discuss the current state of two kinds of Cu-exchanged zeolite, specifically, Cu/SSZ-13 and Cu/SAPO-34, belonging to the CHA topology. In consideration of the extreme depth and breadth in the domain of zeolite-base SCR catalyst, a complete and comprehensive discussion of all aspects is neither practical nor necessary within this review. Thus, we emphasize the zeolite synthesis, NH3-SCR mechanisms, zeolite poisoning mechanisms and corresponding poisoning-resistant strategies, hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms and corresponding protective strategies. We begin by expounding the controlled distribution of T atom in CHA zeolite, uncovering the relationship between controlled synthesis, framework structure and active centers, comparing the differences of copper ion exchange methods, emphasizing the ultrafast and continuous flow synthesis of zeolites for industrial production. Subsequently, we sum up the current state of the NH3-SCR mechanisms. And then, we introduce the sulfur/alkali (alkaline) metal/phosphorus poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms, more importantly, corresponding poisoning-resistant and protective strategies are proposed. Finally, we briefly summarize and provide an outlook to future research directions. Throughout the review, we highlight the structure-performance correlation and try to narrow the gap between current Cu/CHA zeolite and the industrialized application. We hope to construct a linkage between next generation of catalysts and real-world applicable demands to meet the escalating emission regulations in the near future. 2 Recent progress in the zeolite synthesis 2.1 Controlled distribution of T atoms in zeolite Generally speaking, the identities and numbers of exchanged Cu species of Cu/CHA are complicated by multiple factors such as the synthesis strategies, the Si/Al ratio [26], the Cu/Al ratio [27,28], T atom distribution (e.g., the Al atom in SSZ-13, the Si atom in SAPO-34) and so on. As we all know, the distribution of T atom in the zeolite framework will affect catalytic activity and selectivity [29,30]. Here, we will discuss recent developments in controlling the distribution of Al and Si atoms within the SSZ-13 and SAPO-34, respectively. 2.1.1 Controlled distribution of Al atoms in SSZ-13 The catalytic and adsorption properties of SSZ-13 strongly rely on the controlled distribution of Al atoms [31–34]. Generally speaking, the possibility of Al-O-Al sequence within the SSZ-13 framework was ruled out by the Löwenstein rule, the algebraic forms can conveniently be described the local Al arrangement, where Al atoms separated by at least three Si atoms (Al-O(-Si-O)n-Al, n≥3) could exclusively balance monovalent cation (e.g., NH4+, Na+) (denoted here as “isolated Al”), as revealed in Fig. 2 (a), and two Al atoms separated by one or two Si atoms (Al-O(-Si-O)n-Al, n = 1, 2) could balance a divalent cation (e.g., Cu2+, Co2+) (denoted here as “paired Al”), as shown in Fig. 2(b) [35]. The interzeolite conversion of FAU (structure code for faujasite framework) into SSZ-13 using structure-directing agents (SDAs) such as N,N,N-trimethyl-1-1-adamantammonium hydroxide cation (TMAda+) [32,36], (benzyltrimethylammonium cations) BTMA+ [37], N,N-dimethylcyclohexylammonium cations (DMCHA+) [38] and tetraethylammonium cations (TEA+) [39,40] has attracted much attention due to its fast crystallization rate. Note that SSZ-13 can also be prepared from FAU in the absence of SDAs [41], and LTA (structure code for Linde type A framework) in the presence of TMAda+ [42]. For instance, low-silica SSZ-13 (Si/Al = 4–6) zeolites could be prepared from FAU as Al precursor and TMAda+ as SDA, which possess plenty of paired Al that can balance divalent Cu2+ or Co2+. In a recent work conducted by Zhang et al. [29], the strong electrostatic interactions between TMAda+ cation and negative SiO- H-OSi supported the preferential formation of 8- membered rings (8MRs) in CHA, whilst the strong electrostatic interactions between DMCHA+ cation and negative Si-O-Al induced the preferential formation of 6- membered rings (6MRs) in CHA, thus, the latter possessing more paired Al atoms occupied 6MRs provided stronger hydrothermally stable sites and better high temperature SCR performance than the former. Alternatively, different high-silica SSZ-13 zeolites (e.g., Si/Al>10) could be hydrothermally synthesized in alkaline media by means of TMAda+ and Na+ (e.g., Si/Al = 10–65) [26], in alkaline media by means of only TMAda+ (e.g., Si/Al = 15–30) [35] or in fluoride media by means of only TMAda+ (e.g., Si/Al = 10-∞) [38]. As discussed in detail by Gounder et al. [35], three scenarios existed in controlling the isolated Al and paired Al in CHA zeolite: (1) when only TMAda+ was present, SSZ-13 zeolites (Si/Al = 15–30) that synthesized in hydroxide media and comprised exclusively isolated Al that were unable to balance divalent Cu2+ or Co2+. (2) when both TMAda+ and Na+ were present, simultaneously keeping (TMAda+ + Na+)/Al and other synthesis parameters invariable, interestingly, the synthesized SSZ-13 zeolites with Si/Al = 15 ratio generated fractions of paired Al sites, which were in direct proportion to the increasing Na+ content. (3) when TMAda+ was equal to Na+, crystallized SSZ-13 at different Si/Al ratios via changing Al content generated a density of paired Al sites, which resulted in a random Al distribution abided by Löwenstein’s rule. Proposed role of TMAda+ and Na+ on controlling Al distribution in the SSZ-13 zeolites was illustrated in Fig. 2(c) and (d). In principle, high-silica zeolites can be obtained with almost perfect or few defects in the fluoride media (e.g., NH4F, NH4HF2, HF), but prepared with more defects in the conventional alkaline media, because the fluoride ion can balance the positive charge of the template agent, on the contrary, in the absence of fluoride ion, the positive charge of the template agent is balanced by the negative charge caused by framework defects. No matter whether TMAda+ is in alkaline media or fluoride media, the obtained SSZ-13 comprises exclusively isolated Al, Additionally, when only TMAda+ was present, higher Si/Al (e.g., 60 < Si/Al<100) ratios zeolite could be synthesized in fluoride media than that in alkaline media, because fluoride ion compensates superfluous cationic charges derived from the TMAda+ and eliminates the formation of framework defects [12]. 2.1.2 Controlled distribution of Si atoms in SAPO-34 It has been well-documented that both SCR activity and durability of Cu/SAPO-34 are intensively dependent on the Si distribution. Meanwhile, as has already been known, the different organic SDAs affect the Si distribution and framework charge density in SAPO-34 supports, and the Si distribution further adjusts the acid distribution and the Cu speciation. The SAPO-34 could be regarded as the substitution of P atoms in AlPOs by Si. If the mole ratio of (Si + P)/Al = 1, Si atom will substitute P (SM2) and form the Si (4OAl) species. If the mole ratio of (Si + P)/Al>1, two silica atoms will substitute adjacent P and Al atoms (SM3), they could generate the Si(nOAl) (n = 0–3) structures. Shen et al. applied four SDAs [(morpholine (MOR), diethylamine (DEA), TEA (triethylamine) and tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH)] to illustrate the effect of SDAs on Si distribution in SAPO-34 [43], where the templates of TEA and TEAOH tended to form more Si (nOAl, n = 1–3) structures than that MOR and DEA. In general, different acid properties are produced by the diverse Si coordination structures, and the Si (nOAl) (n = 0–4) presents the decreasing acidity as following: Si(1OAl) > Si (2OAl) > Si (3OAl) > Si(4OAl) > Si(0OAl) [44]. Note that Si(0OAl) structure cannot generate acid site, which has been proved disadvantageous to the catalytic performance of NH3-SCR [45–47]. Additionally, Woo et al. [48] reported that Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts were synthesized by various SDAs displayed different deactivation behaviors at low temperature moisture atmosphere, as will be described below in Section 5.2. Nowadays, it should be noted that the molecular-level influence of various SDAs on different Si distribution in SAPO-34 has been not clear yet, and much effort should be made on this aspect, especially the mysterious failure at low temperatures (<100 °C) exposed to moisture [48,49]. 2.2 Copper exchange in zeolite 2.2.1 Aqueous ion-exchange (AIE) Traditionally, AIE method is the most common technology to obtain Cu/CHA catalysts for NH3-SCR, the copper exchange capacity in supported zeolite can be regulated by changing the aqueous solution concentration of the copper salt. Gao et al. [50] reported that the isolated Cu2+ species were located close to the sites in 6MRs at low IE level of ∼20 %, which coordinated with 2 Al atoms (denoted here as Cu2+-2Z), forming 3 or 4 CuO bonds with lattice oxygen, as the IE level increased, the Cu2+ species might populate inside CHA cages next to 8MRs as [Cu(OH)]+ species, which coordinated to the 1 Al sites (denoted here as [Cu(OH)]+-Z), forming 3 CuO bonds (two lattice oxygen together with OH) [51–53]. Both these two types of Cu species are active in SCR, however, Cu2+-2Z and [Cu(OH)]+-Z behave differently in many aspects, for instance, Cu2+-2Z sites present superior resistant to than [Cu(OH)]+-Z in sulfur poisoning, phosphorus poisoning and hydrothermal aging and so on (as we will discuss below). Furthermore, interaction between NH3 and the Cu cations located in 8MR sites is more active than that in 6MR sites [54]. With the further increasing of the IE level will lead to the formation of Cu oxides (CuOx), which are active for undesirable NH3 oxidation and NO oxidation. AIE faces many challenges when Cu exchanges into SAPO-34 due to the hydrophilicity of the framework and via irreversible hydrolysis under aqueous conditions [47], more importantly, CuOx species are always accompany with isolated Cu2+, because isolated Cu2+ ions in relatively low charge density of SAPO-34 unit cells are less thermodynamically stable than CuOx clusters, beyond that, it is of great significance to control the pH of the exchange solution when adapting AIE procedures to avoid the CuOx species. 2.2.2 “One-pot” synthesis 2.2.2.1 One-pot synthesis of Cu/SSZ-13 In 1985, a breakthrough in synthesis of SSZ-13 zeolite was discovered by Zones, however, the relatively expensive SDA of N,N,N-trimethyl-1-adamantammonium hydroxide (TMAdaOH) was used [55], thus hindering large-scale industrial production. For this reason, the milestone work conducted by Ren et al., who designed a one-pot synthesis of Cu/SSZ-13 catalyst utilizing the cheap Cu-tetraethylenepentamine (Cu-TEPA) complex as the new template rather than the TMAdaOH, in comparison to the traditional Cu2+ IE route, both a higher Cu loading and better dispersion of Cu speciation were achieved [56,57]. The synthesis mechanism of Cu/SSZ-13 zeolite in the presence of Cu-TEPA is illustrated in Fig. 3 (a). However, the above in-situ synthesized Cu/SSZ-13 zeolites tactics has the following flaws: (1) the overloaded Cu readily inducing the formation of CuOx clusters. (2) relatively low Si/Al ratio (Si/Al = 4–7), (3) unsatisfactory hydrothermal stability. Given these disadvantages, recently, some post-treatment strategies including HNO3 [58,59]. NH4NO3 [60] and dual-treatment (HNO3 and NH4NO3) [61] to treat the as-synthesized Cu/SSZ-13 have been developed, where HNO3 optimized the copper species distribution, NH4NO3 reduced the Cu/Al ratios efficiently and avoided the aggregation of isolated Cu2+ ions into CuOx clusters in high-temperature steam. It is worth mentioning that TMAdaOH together with Cu-TEPA as a co-SDA can contribute to a controlled Si/Al ratios and Cu loading [26,62,63]. 2.2.2.2 One-pot synthesis of Cu/SAPO-34 Inspired by one-pot synthesis of Cu/SSZ-13, the direct synthesis methodology of Cu/SAPO-34 using Cu-TEPA as a single template was developed by Corma et al. [46]. In the last several years, the one-pot synthesis of Cu/SAPO-34 was rationalized by integrating a Cu-amine complex [e.g., Cu-TEPA, Cu-triethylenetetramine (Cu-TETA)] with a SDA including [MOR [64], TEAOH [65], DEA [66] and propylamine (PA)] as co-template [67,68], which could direct the crystallization and easily control Cu loading of SAPO-34 products. It should be pointed out that the classical solvothermal synthesis of zeolites exhibits some drawbacks: (1) equipment safety considerations, (2) low space time yields and (3) producing much industrial wastewater. For this purpose, the synthesis of different zeolites via a simple and generalized solvent-free route was developed by Xiao et al. [69,70], which presented huge potential for green synthesis of zeolites. Yu et al. [71] reported a one-pot and solvent-free synthesis Cu/SAPO-34 assisted by Cu-TEPA added in the precursor, which reduced waste production, accelerated the crystallization rate and increased the zeolite yield. As shown in Fig. 3(b). This methodology shows promise for considerable environmental and economic benefit owing to the avoidance of solvents in synthesis. In the future, more sustainable routes such as organotemplate-free synthesis and solvent-free synthesis should be developed [72,73]. 2.2.3 Solid-state ion-exchange (SSIE) For the purposes of developing new technologies, we will focus on introducing the SSIE method, which is most suitable for three scenarios: (1) metal ions that are easily oxidized in air (Fe2+, Cu+, etc.), (2) the formation of large solvation shells for some multivalent metal ions (e.g., Cu2+) leads to steric hindrance during AIE, and (3) zeolite framework is easily attacked by water (e.g., SAPO-34). 2.2.3.1 High temperature SSIE (HT-SSIE) Zeolite support (H-form or NH4-form), is mixed and grinded with metal salt and then heated at high temperature (e.g., 800 ℃) in air or N2 atmosphere to favor the ion exchange process. For instance, Wang et al. [74–76] demonstrated that the isolated Cu ions were eventually exchanged into the anchor sites of SSZ-13 and SAPO-34 by SSIE with excellent performance in the NH3-SCR reaction. In other successful examples, SSIE was conducted by calcinating a dry powder of H-SAPO-34/CuO mixtures to clarify the differences with one-pot and AIE method [76,77]. A typical SSIE process is presented in Fig. 4 (a) [78]. Recently. Chang et al. [79] developed a ball milling assisted SSIE to prepare Cu/SAPO-34, the results suggested that ball milling could be in favor of increasing the amount of isolated Cu2+ ions compared with physically mix. Compared with AIE, it's worth noting that HT-SSIE provides convenience for the introduction of isolated Cu2+ species into SSZ-13 and SAPO-34 crystals and simplifies the preparation process without continuous washing, filtration and drying, but owing to the high temperatures required to promote SSIE, some structural damage and inadequate reaction of CuOx cannot be avoided [80,81]. 2.2.3.2 Ammonia-assisted SSIE In contrast with conventional SSIE, more recently, the so-called [NO + NH3]-SSIE method is simple as it only involves two operation steps: mixing the metal oxide (e.g., CuO, Cu2O) and zeolite support (H-form or NH4-form), and flushing both NH3 and NO over the mixture, [NH3]-SSIE is refer to only treated by NH3, accordingly [82]. Shwan et al. reported NH3-assisted Cu-exchanged zeolites (MFI, BEA, CHA) at temperatures below 250 °C via NH3 solvated Cu+ species (e.g., [Cu(NH3)2]+), the obtained Cu/zeolites were active for NH3-SCR [83], where the CuO was first reduced to Cu+ when treated in NO and NH3 and then coordinated to NH3 molecules to generate a linear [Cu(NH3)2]+ complex, the formation of such complex could penetrate through the zeolite pore and be loosely bound to zeolite framework, thus the high mobile complex may considerably reduce the required SSIE temperature. Note that these processes were similar to the recent low temperature reduction half-cycle SCR mechanisms (as will be discussed in Section 3.1). As reported by Vennestrøm group, the linear [Cu(NH3)2]+ complex was verified by experimental installations due to the [Cu(NH3)2]+ complex has a very characteristic Cu-K pre-edge in the X-ray absorption spectrum (XANES) at 8983 eV [84], as shown in Fig. 4(b). Further experiments results showed that [NH3]-SSIE was controlled by the formation of this complex at lower temperatures (150−300 °C), whereas above >350 °C, the complex underwent decomposition and therefore limited the exchange. Interestingly, the effect of copper sources and the addition of NO cannot be ignored in [NH3]-SSIE, if CuO was used as the Cu source, the rate of SSIE was limited by the CuO→Cu2O reduction with NH3, however, introduction of NO facilitated the reduction process and removed this limitation. If Cu2O was used as Cu source, the rate of SSIE was limited by formation of the dynamic [Cu(NH3)2]+ complexes and their migration, in this case, the effect of NO could be omitted because the SSIE was carried out efficiently using NH3 alone. Thus, from a preparative perspective, the selection of Cu2O and NH3-SSIE is therefore advantageous [85]. Coupled with DFT calculation results, Chen et al. investigated the energetic conditions for the SSIE of Cu into SSZ-13 starting from Cu2O (111) [86], adsorption of NH3 on Cu2O (111) also induced the formation of a linear [Cu(NH3)2]+ complex. The authors suggested that the Cu ion was preferably solvated with NH3, which supported the assumption that the complex could be a part of the SCR mechanism, which was helpful for us to understand the low temperature standard SCR mechanism. (detailed discussions will be seen in Section 3.1). 2.2.3.3 Low temperature SSIE (LT-SSIE) Clearly, HT-SSIE process is energy-intensive and ammonia is a toxic gas, which may limit the industrialization of HT-SSIE and [NH3]-SSIE technologies. Considering this, an environmentally friendly LT-SSIE method has been developed by Ma et al. [87], namely, the easily decomposed copper salt precursor (e.g., CuAc2, Cu(NO3)2 and CuCl2) are highly dispersed on zeolite host (H-form or NH4-form) by impregnation methods. After calcination at low temperature (e.g., 300 °C) in air atmosphere, the catalysts could be completely activated. The LT-SSIE process could be regarded as the easily decomposed copper salt shifts the equilibrium to the right side due to Le Chatelier’s principle, resulting in a quick and complete ion-exchange of Cu2+ ions with zeolite. Ma et al. also [87] applied the DFT calculations to manifest the diffusion of CuAc2 through SSZ-13 channels, as shown in Fig. 4(c). Note that LT-SSIE method has not been reported on the SAPO-34 and other type zeolites yet, thus, this technique deserves more comprehensive and extensive studies. 2.3 Ultrafast and continuous flow synthesis of zeolites Continuous flow synthesis is regarded as a potential alternative for scaling up the production of zeolites, because it can conquer the disadvantage of batch-wise synthesis. Up to now, some excellent review articles and research papers have been published by Liu and coworkers [88,89]. The ultrafast synthesis facilitates to ensure a continuous flow synthesis. As for ultrafast synthesis, several effective methods can speed up the crystallization of zeolites including: (1) microwave-assisted synthesis of zeolites. (2) the interzeolite transformation of FAU into other zeolites and (3) accelerated by hydroxyl free radicals [88]. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), a general scheme of the ultrafast synthesis was proposed [88]. Generally speaking, zeolite crystallization can be divided into the following several continuous processes: (1) mix: Al and Si or other precursors, organic SDAs and solvents are mixed homogeneously. (2) age: the aging plays a decisive role in ultrafast synthesis. First of all, the homogeneity and the nutrient species are achieved for sake of direct crystal growth. And then, the mass and energy exchange between inorganic, organic species and solvents will gradually reach equilibrium. Finally, the adequate aging may produce sufficient nucleus. (3) nucleation: Nucleation is generally regarded as the major kinetic barrier in the synthesis. Seed can reduce crystallization time, increase crystallinity to avoid the generation of hybrid phase, and adjust the particle size in the final product. Note that sufficient surface (i.e. growth site) is always beneficial for growth, so smaller crystal particles are often used as seed. (4) fast crystal growth: a gradual increase in crystal size at a stable nucleus. The tubular reactor with high surface-to-volume ratio could ensure quick heat transfer rate to avoid the thermal lag generating the hetero-crystalline phases, high temperatures are good for an ultrafast crystal growth. In theory, the higher appropriate temperature is, the faster crystallization rate will be. 2.3.1 Ultrafast and continuous flow synthesis of SSZ-13 A highly viscosity and cohesive gel takes place during heating treatment, which restricts the practical application of continuous flow synthesis. Liu et al. [90] designed a two-stage synthesis strategy for SSZ-13, where the introduction of the supernatant liquid to the gel in the middle of the process made sure the fluidity of the gel to achieve SSZ-13 in 10 min, the Cu-exchanged SSZ-13 catalyst performed outstanding deNOx activity. A general guideline and procedure for continuous-flow preparation of SSZ-13 is shown in Fig. 5(b). In order to solve hydrodynamic failure, in the same group, Zhu [91] developed a more general approach, an emulsion method, to ultrafast stable-flow synthesis of zeolite, where a emulsion system with the aid of a Teflon-lined pipe reactor design were constructed to ensure high homogeneity and decreased axial diffusion, the crystallization of SSZ-13 took place within 2 min. This approach paves the way to avoid the deposition issues in the continuous flow synthesis. 2.3.2 Ultrafast and continuous flow synthesis of SAPO-34 The preparation technology of SAPO-34 shows slight differences with that of SSZ-13 [92]. The crystallization mechanism of SAPO-34, however, is regarded to be distinguishing. For one thing, as discussed above, the SM2 and SM3 substitution mechanisms of SAPO-34 lead to different Si distributions, for another, even in traditional hydrothermal synthesis conditions, a pair of hybrid phases like AFI/CHA or CHA/AEI easily occur in SAPO zeolite, which is attributed to the similarities in chemical compositions and structure. A question then arises as to whether ultrafast and continuous flow synthesis could be similarly applied to pure SAPO-34 [93]. Based on the Ostwald step rule, the crystallization of zeolites follows a route that the first generated phase appears less thermodynamically stable, which will transform into a more stabilized phase and then the next until the most stabilized phase. Based on the crystallization kinetics differences, with the aid of milled seed, by mechanical milling the Al and Si precursors and precisely controlling reaction temperature, which were critically contributed to accelerate crystallization rate of SAPO-34. SAPO-5 and SAPO-34 were successfully synthesized by Liu et al. within 5 and 10 min in a tubular reactor, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5(c) [93–95]. In a word, the kinetics, the thermodynamics, and the hydrodynamics cannot be considered independently, the ultrafast and continuous flow synthesis of SSZ-13 and SAPO-34 will lay a solid foundation for the large-scale production in industry. 3 Breakthroughs in the NH3-SCR mechanisms 3.1 Standard SCR mechanism near 200 °C A general consensus about standard NH3-SCR reaction mechanisms has been not achieved. Standard SCR is a redox reaction involved in NO and NH3 [Eq. (1)]. (1) 4NH3 + 4NO + O2 = 4N2 + 6H2O Complexity of above reaction is pretty obvious in the stoichiometry in regard to passage/adsorption/activation among NH3, NO, and O2. Depending on whether NO chemisorbs or only weakly interacts with the chemisorbed NH3 complexes, the reaction can be classified as a Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism and an Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, respectively [96]. Based on lots of studies, a general SCR reaction mechanism over metal-based oxide and zeolite catalysts is suggested as presented in Fig. 6 (a) [1], however, for Cu/CHA catalysts, the mechanisms shown above are very general, lacking many molecular-level details. In this case, there are still many unusual phenomena that cannot be fully explained [97]: (1) at low temperatures (<250 °C), a wondrous linear SCR rate versus (Cu loading)2 correlation was found, while at elevated temperatures (>350 °C), SCR rates have a linear relation with Cu loading. Puzzlingly, in the temperature range 250−350 °C, the rate and conversion of NOx reduction decreased with increasing temperature, demonstrating a light-off curve with typical seagull shape. (2) whether the often-detected Cu-nitrates involved in the SCR reaction cycle. (3) what is the functionality of Brønsted acid sites in the catalytic reaction. So far, the Cu2+/Cu+ redox pairs in standard NH3-SCR was well-established, as proved by the observation of both DFT calculation and in operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) [54,98–101]. Specifically, the mechanism for the reduction half-cycle (Cu2+→Cu+) has been reasonably recognized, while the oxidation half-cycle (Cu+→Cu2+) still remains an on-going debate [102]. In reduction half-cycle part, NO alone had been considered as reductant from Cu2+ to Cu+, but the XANES spectra at 8983 eV attributed to Cu+ could never be discovered exposure to NO at 200 °C [103]. NH3 alone had also been supposed to reduce Cu2+ to Cu+, but the Cu reduction rates exposed to NH3 discovered in XANES of Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts were much slower than that SCR catalytic turn over frequency [98,104]. Combining these experimental results, it is reasonable to propose that NO and NH3 collectively reduced Cu2+ to Cu+ during the reduction half-cycle, identical conclusions were obtained by Paolucci et al. [105], the authors pointed out both NO and NH3 were essential for Cu2+ reduction to Cu+, meanwhile, the oxidation from Cu+ to Cu2+ by NO and O2 was also indispensable. In oxidation half-cycle part, as we all know, the interactions between Cu ions and NH3 are superior to NOx, O2 and H2O. In an operando XAS/XES research by Lomachenko et al. [101], mobile Cu2+ and Cu+ sites solvated by NH3 were proved as the main Cu sites at low temperature. Based on these studies, the milestone work by Paolucci et al., who predicted the existence of mobile [Cu(NH3)2]+ species inside the CHA by employing ab initio metadynamics [103,106], as previously discussed in the [NH3]-SSIE section, the SSIE was controlled by the formation and migration of this linear [Cu(NH3)2]+ complex. Based on the peak fitting of SCR kinetic experimental data [102,107], the SCR rates are not linearly related to Cu/Al ratios but (Cu/Al ratios)2 at low Cu loadings at 200 °C, however, SCR rates increase linearly with Cu/Al ratios at 380 °C. To rationalize this kinetic behavior, thus, the startling and provocative notion of “transient Cu dimers” (in fact, referred to transient “[Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+” intermediate, as discussed in detail below) was reasonably proposed by Gao et al. in 2014 [107], who proposed that the participation of two [Cu(NH3)2]+ centers were required for the oxidation half-cycle at low temperature standard NH3-SCR. Such complexes were loosely bound to the zeolite, as one mobile [Cu(NH3)2]+ species could deviate ∼9 Å from their “anchor” points and encounter another mobile [Cu(NH3)2]+, but they were unable to directly combine without linking an O2 molecule in between [102,106,108]. The two neighboring [Cu(NH3)2]+ together with an O2 then combined to form [Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+ as shown in (2), (2) 2[Cu(NH3)2]+ + O2 = [Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+ calculated activation energies indicated that such a process was accessible, however, whose formation in case of low Cu loadings was the rate-limiting step. With Cu loadings increasing, two complexes encountered with each other more facilely and frequently, transport of [Cu(NH3)2]+ and the relevant O2 activation were no longer rate-determining step. It should be noted that reduction of one O2 molecule to two O2− ions involves with four electrons, while oxidation of two Cu+ to two Cu2+ involves with two electrons, thus, NO must be oxidized to NO2 to donate two electrons to keep charge balance [2,102], as shown in Eq. (3). (3) [Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+ + NO = [Cu(NH3)2]+-O-[Cu(NH3)2]+ + NO2 In another study, Falsig et al. [109] applied DFT calculations and also confirmed O2 activation on neighboring Cu atoms was energetically much more favorable than that on isolated Cu ion, in the presence of NO, the elongation of the OO bond in O2 reacted with the NO to generate the NO2 species, and oxidation state for the Cu ion was from Cu+ to Cu2+ to achieve charge balance, which could be proved by the change of the magnetic moment from 0 to 0.4. Finally, water molecule reacted with [Cu(NH3)2]2+-O-[Cu(NH3)2]2+, forming the [(NH3)2-Cu-OH]+, thus the complete low-temperature SCR catalytic cycle was completed. The SCR catalytic cycle at low temperature proposed by Gao et al. is presented in Fig. 6(b) [102]. 3.2 Standard SCR mechanism near 350 °C Some evidences indicated standard SCR mechanism near 350 °C likely involved with only monomeric Cu active sites. (1) NH3-TPD, EPR and XAS/XES experiments have provided evidences for the escape of NH3 from Cu between 250 °C and 400 °C, namely, a process of Cu ions from solvated to desolvated [13,101]. (2) the increase in apparent activation energy from 60 to 90 kJ/mol to ∼140 kJ/mol suggests the changes of SCR mechanism [107]. The most probable cupriferous reaction intermediate that should stoichiometrically decompose to N2 and H2O, where one N atom derives from NH3 and another N atom derives from NO, simultaneously, the stoichiometric ratio of H to O must be 2:1 in the intermediate. In view of these facts, a nitrosoamide-like intermediate (e.g., NO-Cu-NH2) or an ammonium nitrite-like intermediate (e.g., NO2-Cu-NH4 or HNO2-Cu-NH3) seems the most likely. This leads to two possible reactant activation scenarios [110]: (1) NH3 is activated by Cu2+ via NH bond fracture to form a Cu+-NH2 complex and a H+. Note that this process is accompanied by an electron transfer from N to Cu, the N atom now has a formal oxidation state of -2 in the resultant Cu+-NH2 complex. In this case, NO (with +2 oxidation state for N) can directly interact with this complex to generate a Cu+-NH2NO intermediate, which can then rearrange and decompose to N2 and H2O, as shown in Eq. (4–6). (4) Cu2+ + NH3 = Cu+-NH2 + H+ (5) Cu+-NH2 + NO = Cu+-NH2NO + H+ (6) Cu+-NH2NO = Cu+ +N2 + H2O A recent work from Beale et al. [111] group, they developed a modulation excitation (ME) IR spectroscopy approach to directly detect the dynamic species involved in a SCR reaction, highlighting two key intermediates, namely, Cu+-NH2NO and Cu-NO3, importantly, Cu+-NH2NO as a key reaction intermediate has been also identified by Paolucci et al. and Janssens et al. [105,112]. Alternatively, (2) NO is activated by Cu2+, forming a species with +3 oxidation state for N that are reactive toward non-activated NH3. The thus-generated possible intermediates include: NO2 −, NO+, HONO [113]. For NO2 −, Janssens et al. [112] proposed that the Cu-nitrate intermediate reacted with NO to produce Cu-bound intermediate and NO2, the relevant reactions are shown in Eq. (7–9). (7) Cu+ + NO + O2 = Cu2+-NO3 − (8) Cu2+-NO3 − + NO = Cu2+-NO2 − + NO2 (9) Cu2+-NO2 − + NH3 = Cu2+(NH3)-NO2 − = [Cu(OH)]+ + N2 + H2O For, NO+, recently, Szanyi et al. discovered the generated NO+ species were bound to both Cu+ and Cu2+ centers during NO chemisorption by means of in situ FTIR on Cu/SSZ-13 [114–116]. (10) Cu2+ + NO = Cu+-NO+ Baik et al. [117] used the DFT to verify the generation of NO+ was facilitated by the copper site, because the cationic NO+ appeared highly reactive towards nucleophiles, which could be attacked by NH3 to produce the nitrosamine intermediate. In order to consume the nitrosamine intermediate, the zeolite can be considered as a “proton sponge”, collecting from and donating to a variety of proton intermediates, enabling Brønsted acid to catalyze decomposition of the nitrosoamine into N2 and H2O. As for the role of Brønsted acid in SCR [98,118,119], which has been identified to play a crucial part in NH3-SCR reaction in many literatures. For example, in situ impedance spectroscopy and quantum chemical calculations have verified that both NH4 + and NH4 +·(NH3)n complexes could act as extra paths or carriers for the transmission of protons and ultimately augment the proton conductivity. For HONO, the NO+ species can interact with H2O to generate HONO. In particular, theoretical calculations demonstrate that a [Cu(OH)]+-Z active site can also interact with NO to form HONO with rather low energy barriers [102]. Lastly, HONO can then react with NH3 to form an NH4NO2 intermediate that can readily decompose to N2 and H2O, as shown in Eq. (11–13). (11) NO+ + H2O = HNO2 + H+ (12) [Cu(OH)]+ + NO = Cu+ + HONO (13) HONO + NH3 = NH4NO2 = N2 +H2O From above discussions, the overall proposed catalytic cycle by Janssens et al. is suggested in Fig. 6(c) [112]. 3.3 Fast NH3-SCR mechanism (14) NO + NO2 + 2NH3 = 2N2 + 3H2O Currently, a clear mechanism for fast NH3-SCR has not yet been achieved. The key contradiction lies on whether the fast SCR reaction is involved with the charge transfer between Cu and NOx. Two scenarios are possible. The work done by McEwan et al. [120], who concluded that only Cu2+ was present under fast SCR conditions, which coincided with the proposal by Grossale et al. [121], because Cu+ was not detected in fast SCR via operando XAS, which is in contrast to the standard SCR [122]. The role of Cu2+ may be not involved with redox behavior but only to offer a reaction location for the formation of intermediates. The following reaction [Eq. (15–17)] pathways summarize this first scenario: (15) NO + NO2 = N2O3 (16) N2O3 + H2O = 2HONO (17) Cu2+-NH3 + HONO = 2N2 + 3H2O On the contrary, if Cu2+ and NOx exist electron transfer behavior, except that the Cu+ re-oxidation step is achieved by its reacting with NO2 instead of O2. Mao [123] et al. presented a detailed step-by-step NH3-SCR mechanism over Cu/SAPO-34 from periodic DFT calculations. For fast SCR section, they suggested the Cu+/NH4 + was oxidized by the NO2 to produce Cu2+ and NH4NO2, Finally, NH4NO2 decomposed into N2 and H2O. In particular, one possible fast SCR mechanism can be described in Fig. 6(d). Recently, Cui et al. [124] conducted a detail fast NH3-SCR kinetics experiments, the reaction apparent activation energies as high as ∼ 160 kJ/mol predicted that the rate-limiting kinetics correlated with the participation of NH4NO3 in fast SCR mechanism. Note that none of above proposed mechanisms could provide a complete catalytic cycle over the whole operating temperatures. Applying more advanced characterization tools in combination with molecular-scale computational models are needed to capture comprehensive and solid information in the future. 4 Poisoning mechanisms and poison-resistant strategies 4.1 Sulfur poisoning mechanism In practical operating conditions, the Cu/CHA zeolites are pretty susceptible to SO2 exhausts in diesel even at ultra-low sulfur level (below 15 ppm) and their SCR activity will severely drop, especially at low temperatures (<350 °C). The observed degree of deactivation varies depending on multiple factors such as gas composition [125], sulfur amount [126], reaction temperature [127]. It is crucial to uncover the sulfur poisoning mechanisms and develop effective poison-resistant strategies for Cu/CHA. The associated mechanisms between sulfur and SCR activity have been widely studied. Pivotal insights include but not limited the following points: (1) the deposition of ammonium sulfate and Cu sulfate species can invoke the reduction of active centers and the blockage of the pores, which severely suppress low-temperature NH3-SCR, particularly below 350 ℃ [128], the high temperature SCR activity, on the other hand, seems to remain unaffected or less sensitive to the sulfur poisoning [129]. (2) ammonium sulfate decomposing at around 350 °C can therefore be easily eliminated, while Cu sulfate species are needed much higher desulfation temperatures to recover. (3) SO3 poisoning causes much more significant deactivation than that SO2 due to more copper sulfate formation [130,131]. 4.1.1 Different sulfate species formation Shen et al. [132] indicated that SAPO-34 support was less sensitive to sulfur species, the drop of the NH3-SCR activity could be ascribed to the decrease of isolated Cu2+ ions, which could be proved by obvious declining intensity for bands at 891 cm−1 and 844 cm−1 in DRIFTS spectra on Cu/SAPO-34, resulting in cupric sulfates/sulfites species. Su et al. [133] discovered that three different sulfate species deposited on the zeolite surface including H2SO4, CuSO4 and Al2(SO4)3. H2SO4 species could be completely recovered at 450 °C due to the low decomposition temperature, otherwise, the substantial CuSO4 and Al2(SO4)3 formation led to the failure of complete recovery for Cu/SAPO-34 even in 650 °C. A comprehensive study performed by Jangjou et al. [134], they found two poisoning mechanism scenarios: (1) stable CuxSOy species were formed in presence of only SO2, elevated temperatures (>480 °C) were required to desorb. (2) less stable (NH4)xCuySOz species were formed in presence of both NH3 and SO2, 80 % of the original activity was recovered when treated in 350 °C. More importantly, in terms of thermodynamic stability, NH3 could impel sulfur species from a stable CuxSOy to a less stable ammonium sulfate at a relatively low temperature, however, Once CuxSOy treated at elevated temperature leading to more stable sulfate species, retreating them with NH3 could not form ammonium sulfate species, as illustrated in Fig. 7 (a). Recently, the joint influence between SO2 and hydrothermal aging has been studied, the high temperature together with SO2 poisoning would dislodge the extra-framework Al and cause permanent deactivation for Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, in this case, no deposit of sulfate was observed but like “CuOx, CuAlOx” species could be seen [135,136] Further effort is required to understand the relationships between sulfur poisoning and other factors like alkali/alkaline earth metal poisoning and phosphorous poisoning. 4.1.2 Different Cu active centers responses to SO2 As for Cu2+-2Z and [Cu(OH)]+-Z, these two types of active sites on Cu/CHA catalysts for NH3-SCR have also been widely investigated [137]. Based on DRIFTS experiments supplemented with DFT calculations, a low-temperature (<200 °C) SO2 poisoning mechanism was proposed by Jangjou et al. [138], they observed that SO2 only adsorbed coupling with NH3 and resulted in the generation of ammonium sulfate on Cu2+-2Z in Cu/SSZ-13, in contrast, the interaction between SO2 and [Cu(OH)]+-Z in led to copper bisulfite species formation, which could be oxidized to generate copper bisulfate at elevated temperature. Namely, [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites are less robust to low-temperature SO2 poisoning than that Cu2+-2Z, as shown in Fig. 7(b).Yang et al. [139] conducted a periodic DFT study on Cu/SAPO-34 and suggested SO2 could easily reacted with [Cu(OH)]+ species in 8MR to form Cu-HSO3 complex, which was kinetically and thermodynamically favorable. Cu-HSO3 would be oxidized by O2 to generate more stable CuSO4. In comparison, H2O and O2 and SO2 would produce copper sulfate species on isolated Cu2+ sites in 6MR. EPR spectroscopy experiments were conducted on Cu/CHA catalysts by Hammershøi et al. [126] to monitor interactions of SO2 with Cu ions, the results indicated SO2 mainly interacted with the EPR-silent [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites, however, the Cu2+-2Z sites were largely unaffected by SO2 exposure, it's worth noting that the apparent activation energies decreased from 65 kJ/mol to 30 kJ/mol after SO2 exposure and that subsequent regeneration at 550 °C returned to 65 kJ/mol, above discussed the low-temperature SCR mechanism may help to understand this phenomenon, namely, the sulfur poisoning of [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites restricts the ability of the catalyst to produce two [Cu(NH3)2]+ centers resulting in the lower activation energies. In the regenerated catalysts, however, the sulfur poisoning of [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites have been largely removed, the ability to form two [Cu(NH3)2]+ centers appears to be unaffected and the activation energies the activation energies are back to original level. More recent evidences by Bergman et al., [140] who proposed that Cu-bisulfates were the most energetically favorable poisoned species, severely deactivating the low-temperature standard SCR performance. 4.1.3 The nature of SO3 poisoning As previously mentioned, DOC will be employed upstream to the SCR catalysts, it is likely that partly SO2 is oxidized to SO3, and even some H2SO4 formation occurs in presence of H2O. Cheng et al. found SO3 poisoning resulted in much more serious deactivation than SO2 poisoning for the Cu/zeolite catalysts, XANES/EXAFS analyses indicated sulfur existed as highly dispersed CuSO4. Kumar and co-workers [141] observed that both SO2 and SO3 performed identical and limited impact on the catalyst performance at 200 ℃, in contrast, at 400 ℃, exposure to the SO3-containing mixture had a more profound poisoning effect through some temperature-activated chemical reaction with Cu/CHA catalysts. To further clarify the details of the SO3 poisoning, Shen et al. [131] proposed the higher SO3/SOx ratio induced the lower NOx conversion due to more isolated Cu2+ transforming to copper sulfate, the SO3 even led to SiO(H)Al bonds cleavage. therefore, the conspicuous impacts of SO3 poisoning cannot be ignored. 4.2 SO2 poisoning-resistant strategies A common executed thermal regeneration has been proven to be a fairly efficient approach to decompose reversible S-poisoning species, however, the extreme hydrothermal aging on SO2 poisoning condition could cause irreversible deactivation and lose almost the entire catalytic activity, in this regard, the zeolites should be carefully designed and constructed to relieve the effect of SO2 poisoning. 4.2.1 Constructing a core-shell structure The core-shell structure catalysts for improving the SO2 tolerance have been widely employed in NH3-SCR reaction. The shells serve as protective layer to restrain the generation and deposition of sulfate species, thus retaining the active centers and the redox property in the core. Liu et al. designed a Fe-Beta@CeO2 core-shell catalyst, the suitable shell thickness of CeO2 could inhibit the formation of sulfate species from clogging the active iron sites and promote the formation of active NO2 and cis-N2O2 − intermediates [142]. In their another study, Fe/Beta@SBA-15 core-shell catalysts were constructed, the mesoporous SBA-15 sheaths suppressed the formation of sulfate species and promoted the reactant molecules accessing to active sites [143]. To utilize excellent redox properties (Ce4+/Ce3+) and oxygen storage function of CeO2-based catalysts, a new structure of hollow CeO2@Fe-ZSM-5 was prepared, the coating of Fe-ZSM-5 shell could restrain the direct interaction between SO2 and CeO2 to improve sulfur resistance [144]. The MnCeOx@ZSM-5 also indicated the mesoporous ZSM-5 zeolite sheath hindered sulfate species deposition on the surface of catalysts [145], according to the above analysis, we can observe that either core or shell material possesses a larger pore size than CHA zeolite, which can enhance the access of reactant molecules to the catalytically active centers, although the CHA core-shell structure material has been rarely reported in SCR reaction, it still shows great potential, because the Cu/SAPO-34 with hierarchical pore structure displays the much stronger resistance of SO2 and H2O even after high-temperature hydrothermal aging at 800 °C, perhaps due to hierarchical pore structure accelerating ammonium sulfate species decomposition [146,147]. 4.2.2 Modification by other extra metal elements to protect active sites Generally, modification by extra elements to protect active sites can be divided into two parts: (1) constructing sacrificial sites to protect active sites. Based on the theory of ionic polarization, if the decomposition temperature of copper sulfate is lower than that of MSO4 (M referred to metal in Cu/CHA catalyst), thus sulfur will preferentially attack MOx species, thereby suppressing formation of copper sulfate and enhancing SO2-tolerance ability [148]. CeO2 being a sacrificial site prone to sulfation has enjoyed extensive studies [144,149], besides, the SO2 may favor combination with PrOx over MnOx, which could form praseodymium sulfate and protect the manganese active sites to some extent [150]. Recently, a novel ZnTi10Ox-Cu/SSZ-13 was designed, where more ZnSO4 species were generated, sparing the Cu2+ active sites from sulfur deactivation [148]. (2) suppressing the formation sulfate species to protect active sites. Adding extra elements such as Ce and Fe could greatly inhibit the deposition of ammonium sulfates and prevent the accumulation of metal sulfites/sulfates. The doping of Ce could efficiently retard the formation of surface sulfation species [5,151]. On account of more sulfur-resistant of Fe than Cu, the synergistic effect of Cu and Fe exhibited higher SO2 resistance [152]. The blocking pores, decreasing acid sites and copper active sites loss are always considered as the primary deactivation causes for the alkali poisoning. Nowadays, investigating alkali/alkaline earth metal poisoning on SCR catalysts is mostly via wetness impregnating its metal salt on Cu/CHA catalysts followed by calcinating. Of particular note is an important promoted interaction between alkali/alkaline earth metals and Cu/CHA catalysts, embodied in the enhanced hydrothermal stabilities, in this case, the alkali/alkaline earth metals modified Cu/SSZ-13 is commonly by means of AIE, the specific discussion was carried out in Section 5.3.2. 4.3.1 Blocking pores and acid sites In consideration of the fact that the diameter of the pore opening in SSZ-13 (3.8˚A) is larger than Mg2+ (1.44 Å), Ca2+ (2.00 Å), Na+ (2.04 Å) and K+ (2.76 Å), these ions might permeate into the zeolite pores, causing the observed decrease in the BET areas and micropore volumes, thereby, suggesting a more restricted accessibility to the catalytically active sites probably due to blocking/filling of the zeolite micropores, inducing a clear drop in SCR activity [159]. Wang et al. [160] observed that the SiO2 or AlPO4 species appeared in Na-containing samples and the BET surface areas declined with increasing Na content, NH3-TPD results revealed the introduction of Na+ decreased the strong Brønsted acid sites (Si-OH-Al) and Lewis acid sites [Si-O(Cu)-Al]. Ma et al. [161] found the big SAPO-34 crystals could be broken into small ones along the crystal defects due to potassium corroding, resulting in the decrease of the surface areas and pore volume. 4.3.2 Copper active sites loss Beside the blocking/filling poisoning mechanism arising from alkali/alkaline earth metal poisoning, the transformation of the isolated Cu2+ to the containing CuOx species was seemingly considered as more pronounced factor for the deactivation of Cu/CHA catalyst. [161,162]. Fan et al. [63] speculated that the higher affinity of Cu/SSZ-13 to accommodate the smaller cations in exchange positions resulting more abundant extra-framework CuOx cluster formation in Mg 2+ poisoning, thus the order of poisoning effect is in the following sequence: Mg > Ca > Na > K. Recent study revealed that both the ion diameter and basic strength of alkali metals were responsible for the poisoning behavior, experimental and computational results indicated the Na+ was more prone to replace Cu2+ and coordinate in 6MR than K+ and Li+ [163]. The order of poisoning effects was as follows: Li+ < K+ < Na+, the CuAlO2 species originated from the migration of isolated Cu2+ ions led to a great loss of NH3-SCR performance. To clarify the difference between Na+ and K+ poisoning. Wang et al. [164] found that the K poisoned catalysts led a more severe deactivation, which was opposite with above results. Note that K+ owns a stronger binding ability and a smaller hydrated ion diameter than Na+, K+ could readily permeate into the CHA framework to exchange with Cu active sites, which leads to the formation of more CuOx species. It can be seen from the above results that although the deactivation mechanisms are analogous, scilicet the isolated Cu2+ transforming to the containing CuOx species, whereas, the priority rating of different ions poisoning still need further study. What needs illustration again is that different alkali/alkaline earth metal introducing methods into Cu/CHA obviously cause disparate effects on the catalysts, in order to understand the effect of Na introduction methods in an atomic level compared with residual and ion-exchanged Na ions as protective additives. Chen et al. [165] shed light on impregnating Na ions induced zeolite SSZ-13 desilicication to form crystal-phase H2Si2O5, as evidenced by XRD and ∼52 ppm in 27Al NMR spectra, DFT results indicated that only the Al(OH)3(OSi)1 configuration was the most relevant species. Structural desilicication and CuOx species formation were simultaneously responsible for the structure damages, especially at hydrothermal aging condition. Among these studies, the deactivation mechanisms of different alkaline metals or single alkaline metal on the SCR catalysts have been commonly focused on. It is worth mentioning that such as alkali salts (e.g., K2CO3, K2SO4 and K3PO4) [166] and cold start wetting effect induced by dissolution of NH3 [167] are also the primary sources of alkali poisoning in the diesel engine exhaust, thus the poisoning effects on the Cu/CHA catalyst need further systematically investigated. Additionally, in real world, Cu/CHA catalysts are inevitably simultaneously challenged by alkali metals poisoning and hydrothermal aging, after mild hydrothermal treatment, alkali metal ions could exchange with acid sites and induce the loss of acidity and active copper ions. Once the co-effect from excess alkali contents and high hydrothermal temperature occurred, even SiO2 and CuAlOx species would form and destroy the zeolite framework, leading to a pronounced deactivation. 4.4 Alkali poisoning-resistant strategies A full understanding of the above alkali poisoning mechanism is vital to rationally designing excellent alkali-resistant deNOx catalysts. Nowadays, there are two possible effective strategies to improve the alkali resistance, namely supplying more acidic sacrificial sites and constructing alkali-trapping sites to protect active sites. 4.4.1 Supplying more acidic sacrificial sites Supplying enough acidic sites or employing strongly acidic supports as sacrificial sites to protect the active centers is a valid strategy to enhance the alkali-resistant ability, where acidic sites will preferentially interact with alkali ions, thus leaving the active species accessible for the NOx reduction. In vanadium-based catalysts, acidic supports or components, such as tungstated zirconia [168], hexagonal WO3 [169,170], sulfated zirconia [171], MoO3 [172] possess rich size-suitable alkali-trapping sites with high specificity at the expense of the acid sacrificial sites. In zeolite-based catalysts, the protonated (H+) form of Y zeolite acting as buffer zone to protect the active Fe2O3 sites, suggested that the HY zeolite might be revealed as an attractive building block for designing an alkali poisoning-resistant catalyst [173], likewise, H-SAPO-34 containing rich Brønsted acid sites (Si-OH-Al, P-OH) provided plenty of ion-exchanged protons to substitute the K, Ca, and Pb ions into the zeolites framework [174], the novel H-SAPO-34-supported ceria-promoted copper oxide catalysts with high redox cycle enhanced the resistance against alkaline and heavy metals, as illustrated in Fig. 8 (a). Although supplying more acidic sacrificial sites will be highly desirable for the alkali resistance in practical applications, the design of such CHA catalysts should be conscientiously considered. 4.4.2 Constructing alkali-trapping sites Inspired by the hollandite-type materials as electrodes applied to alkali metal ion batteries, the hollandite manganese oxide (HMO) and hollandite Mn-Ti oxides (HMT) catalysts have been proved as a protective layer to capture alkali metal ions. Tang et al. [175] pointed out the existence of two types of separate active sites in HMO by the temporal in situ synchrotron XRD patterns coupled with the theoretical calculations: (1) K+ occupied the (0,0,0) sites of the crystal structure of HMO after the annealing of KCl/HMO, which indicated that the alkali-active sites located in the internal tunnels for trapping alkali-metal ions. (2) compared with the {001} facets, the {110} facets of the external surface in HMO became occupied by K+, the catalytic activity decreased dramatically, thus the exposed {110} side facets of the HMO acted as catalytic active sites in SCR reaction. Further evidences proved K+ could spontaneously migrates from the blocked catalytically active surface sites into the internal tunnel space of HMO under normal reaction conditions. An exchange-coordination mechanism against alkali poisoning in HMO catalyst was also proposed by Tang group [176], as shown in Fig. 8(b), where the alkali metal ions initially reacted with protons of HMO via the ion exchange and then were stably fixed at the alkali-trapping sites via the coordination with the oxygen atoms of the cavities with an energy savings. Coupled with the Sanderson electronegativity (χSdn) theory, the χSdn (χSdn = 1.5) of Ti4+ is much lower than that (χSdn = 2.5) of V5+, the alkali metal ions preferentially react with V5+-O-H rather than Ti4+-O-H, which accounts for the deactivation of conventional deNOx catalysts by alkalis. Recently, the HMT promoted Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts were carefully designed [177], in particular, the HMT tunnels capturing the K+ ions via the IE mechanism prevented catalyst from deactivation, then the Cu/SAPO-34 remained insusceptible by alkali metal poisoning, as shown in Fig. 8(c). In fact, other metal oxides with a hollandite structure and unoccupied tunnels should also have the potential to exhibit high alkali resistance. Therefore, simulating the actual poisoning process seems more meaningful and practical [1]. 4.5 Phosphorus poisoning The source of phosphorus is mainly zinc dialkyldithiophosphate (ZDDP), the annexing agent from lubricant oils that causes irreversible deactivation for SCR catalysts in diesel exhaust [178]. In comparison with sulfur poisoning on Cu/CHA catalysts, the academic research on phosphorus-zeolite chemistry, which has, to the best of our knowledge, received little attention so far. The systematic article to elucidate the nature of phosphorus-zeolite chemistry has been reviewed by Weckhuysen et al., the authors focus on the structural and physicochemical influence of phosphorus on H-ZSM-5. Due to the structural difference between H-SSZ-13 and H-ZSM-5, there are also significant diversities in phosphorus poisoning [179]. As for phosphorus poisoning, the common precursor of choice is H3PO4, NH4H2PO4 and (NH4)2HPO4, which are considered to reveal the practical catalyst poisoning properties. For the convenience of discussion, the phosphorus loading in phosphorus poisoning catalyst is currently used about 1.24–4.2 wt. %, which is just a reference value based on many literatures. 4.5.1 Blocking pores and acid sites In the matter of blocking pores, the common introduction of phosphorus to Cu/SSZ-13 is by means of wet impregnation, which leads to phosphorus species on external surface of zeolite. Most of these species are phosphorus oxide (P2O5) metaphosphate (PO3 −) and phosphate (PO4 3-) et al., resulting in the reduction in micropore volume and surface area. The phenomenon becomes more severe with high phosphorus loadings. In terms of blocking acid sites, the presence of phosphorus residing on the zeolite surface will react with surface hydroxyl groups [159,178,180]. In the literatures, it is reported that strong acid sites have almost completely disappeared when phosphorus loadings exceed above 5 wt%. With the phosphorus loadings increasing, the phosphorus species have a tendency to move inside the CHA structure, the electronic environment tetrahedrally coordinated zeolite framework aluminium (TFAl) atoms can be distorted, which has been proposed to arise from hydrogen bonding between hydrogen atoms in phosphorus species and lattice oxygen in zeolite and/or Brønsted acid sites and phosphate oxygen groups. The interaction between phosphorus species and TFAl causes a detectable decrease in TFAl species and a decrease in Brønsted acid sites, especially on harsh aging conditions, where the breaking of SiOAl bonds and generation of SiOH and AlOH groups have occurred, in this case, it can contribute to the severe loss in strong acid sites [179]. As we know from the previous discussions in SCR mechanisms, NH4 + species linked to the Brønsted acid site migrated to the Lewis acid sites and catalyzed decomposition of the nitrosoamine to N2 and H2O. 4.5.2 Copper active sites loss Phosphorus is inclined to interact with copper sites and intensively impacts the electronic and redox property of copper [180]. Xie et al. [178] reported the results of XRD and 27Al and 31P solid-state NMR on phosphorus-poisoned Cu/SSZ-13, revealed that phosphorus could interact with copper to form a P-O-Cu linkage. The re-emerging of δAl(−2) ppm on the catalysts revealed the transition of the Al-O-Cu linkage to a P-O-Cu linkage. In another contribution by Xie, the author observed phosphorus largely impacted the electronic transition property of Cu and charge transfer process, that is, phosphorus poisoning drove the Cu reduction peaks to shift to higher temperatures and reduced a part of Cu2+ to Cu°. which was similar with the phosphorus-poisoned Cu/FER catalyst [180,181], phosphorus tended to interact with copper species (especially exchanged Cu2+ species), thus inhibiting the associated SCR redox function. It should be noted that both Cu2+-2Z and [Cu(OH)]+-Z are SCR active centers, however, the response of these two types active sites to phosphorus poisoning exhibits much discrepancy. In a recently study by Wang and coworkers [182], according to the H2-TPR and XPS analysis, they found that Cu2+-2Z was be apt to P2O5 when P species was present, while PO3 − and (PO4)3- preferred to bind with [Cu(OH)]+-Z, which was attributed to the latter shown a lower binding energy with the zeolite lattice than the former. After hydrothermal treatment, [Cu(OH)]+-phosphate/metaphosphate complexes seemed more possible separated from the zeolite framework than that Cu2+-P2O5 species and formed an extra-framework amorphous AlPO4 phase on high [Cu(OH)]+ content. Overview of the key deactivation mechanisms observed for P is listed in Table 3 . 4.5.3 Disruption of the zeolite framework From the above discussions, obviously, the factors of phosphorus poisoning are not isolated but interactional. On hydrothermal aging, the TFAl in non-poisoned Cu/SSZ-13 will be leached from the lattice attacked by H2O, causing extra-framework aluminium (EFAl) species such as Al2O3 and Al(OH)3, the copper active sites thus lose its anchor point and aggregate into CuOx clusters, which have been commonly reported in many literatures. It is also believed that the generation of Al(OH)3 cannot escape from the small pore SSZ-13 zeolite due to spatial confinement effect. Thus, the aged Cu/SSZ-13 still keeps most original framework [178]. Otherwise, when hydrothermally treating the P-poisoned Cu/SSZ-13, the attraction between phosphates and EFAl was even stronger than that TFAl, the presence of phosphorus triggered the abundant formation amorphous of AlPO4 and accelerated the disruption of the zeolite framework. Therefore, the SCR performance decreased severely [183,184]. A comprehensive phosphorus poisoning mechanism of Cu/SSZ-13 catalyst is shown in Fig. 9 (a). This phenomenon is not limited to 10MR structure zeolite. In addition to this, phosphorus suppressing NH3 oxidation have been reported, which will induce a positive effect on higher temperature SCR performance [185,186]. However, in the case of enhancing hydrothermally stability and suppressing NH3 oxidation, an optimized loading of phosphorus modification is required in the range of 0.62∼1.24 wt.%, also just being a reference value, because the high loading of phosphorus (e.g., above 4 wt.%) will deactivate the Cu/SSZ-13 seriously [159,178]. 4.6.1 Phosphorus-aluminium attraction: formation SAPO interface It has been reported that SAPO materials are extremely hydrothermally stable and keep significant crystal structure even up 1000 °C in steam, which can refer to Cu/SAPO-34. It is proposed that phosphate species can bond with terminal SiOAlOH groups stemming from partially dislodged TFAl species during thermal treatment, which effectively results in the generation of local SAPO interfaces. Zhao et al. [186] reported that introducing phosphorus to Cu/SSZ-13 could improve hydrothermal stability. The NMR and Raman suggested that phosphate species migrated and coordinated with the distorted TFAl, resulting in a local SAPO interface, thus inhibiting zeolite dealumination and structure degradation. A phosphorus stabilization effect is shown in Fig. 9(b). 4.6.2 Phosphorus-containing organic SDA as modification agents Different with impregnating phosphorus on Cu/SSZ-13, utilizing tetraethylphosphonium hydroxide (TEPOH) as both organic SDA and phosphorus modifying agents is another rational strategy to enhance hydrothermal stability. Nevertheless, synthesizing with only P-containing organic SDA will lead to the formation of condensed polyphosphate species, because the excess amount of phosphorus species tend to block the pore network, alternatively, a dual-template organic SDAs (TMAdaOH+ and TEPOH) tactics are developed, regulating the content of TEPOH in the starting reaction mixture can optimize the final phosphorus loading [187,188]. For the as-synthesized catalyst, only one evident feature, belonging to the TEP+, was found at about 42 ppm in the 31P MAS NMR spectrum, for the calcined catalyst, however, broad features ranging from 0 to -40 ppm were clearly found, which were attributed to monomeric and highly condensed phosphate species connected to the zeolite framework. The phosphorus-modified Cu/SSZ-13 performed high deNOx activity and robust hydrothermal stability in the NH3-SCR, this protocol has been successfully applied to a wide variety of phosphorus-modified small-pore zeolites synthesis such as AEI [189,190], AFX and LEV [188], strongly indicating the bright prospect of the phosphorus-modified zeolite for NH3-SCR of NOx. 4.6.3 Phosphorus-CuOx interaction: suppressing NH3 oxidation and NO oxidation The CuOx clusters, which are primarily seated inside the large cages of Cu/SSZ-13, are active for undesirable NH3 oxidation and NO oxidation. Xie et al. [185] discovered that phosphorus largely suppressed NH3 oxidation and NO oxidation, below 300 °C, the impact of phosphorus on the SCR activity was insignificant, but above 300 °C, a facilitating effect was found. In a contribution by Chen et al. [183], they discovered the fresh phosphorus-impregnation catalysts shown a better SCR performance than fresh non-impregnation catalysts above 450 °C at low phosphorus content, even after 750 °C hydrothermal treatment for 12 h, the NOx conversion still kept at a high level. One plausible explanation is that phosphorus can interact with CuOx clusters inside CHA large cages to form copper phosphate species, which weakens the negative effects of NH3 oxidation and NO oxidation, leading to a promotive NOx conversion at high temperature.
