Until now, the fundamental studies about hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms over Cu/CHA have mainly focused on Si/Al ratio [26] and Cu/Al ratio [27,191]. Nevertheless, further efforts are required to understand the hydrothermal deactivation mechanism on atomic level to keep the hydrothermal stability of Cu/CHA zeolites in practical application. 5.1 Hydrothermal deactivation mechanism over Cu/SSZ-13 5.1.1 Nature of dealumination in the structural degradation The comprehensive description of hydrothermal stability over Cu/SSZ-13 on atomic level has been conducted by Gao et al. [52,97]. Upon hydrothermal aging, it has been believed that Brønsted acid sites are prone to hydrolysis. For one thing, the full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of 27Al NMR can be applied as an index for framework degradation. Under severe hydrothermal aging condition, framework distortion induced by dealumination conquers lattice relaxation, leading to Al FWHM of framework to intensify with elevated temperature, specifically, the increasing broadness of TFAl peak is located at ∼58 ppm and the emergence of penta- and octahedrally coordinated Al centers at ∼30 and ∼-10 ppm, respectively. For another, in 29Si NMR spectra, features at -98, -105 and -110 ppm are attributed to Si(2OAl), Si(1OAl) and Si(0OAl), respectively [192] after hydrothermal treatment above 700 °C, -105 ppm peak severely declines, in line with catalyst dealumination [26]. Worst of all, zeolite framework are fully decomposed to SiO2 and Al(OH)3. Fig. 10 (a) illustrates the zeolite hydrolysis process [193]. Note that dealumination and CuOx formation often occur simultaneously after high hydrothermal treatment, it’s necessary to expound the nature and role of copper species [194]. 5.1.2 Nature of copper species in the structural degradation According to reported literatures [51,52,195], the Cu2+-2Z, [Cu(OH)]+-Z and CuOx clusters species could be often quantified by EPR when (1) the overall Cu loading is clear, and (2) EPR active Cu loadings are clear in both hydrated and dehydrated catalysts, which is on account of Cu2+-2Z ions remaining EPR active in both hydrated (e.g., [Cu(H2O)6]2+) and dehydrated state, however, [Cu(OH)]+-Z ions become EPR active in form of hydrated state (e.g., [Cu(OH)(H2O)5]+), but turn to EPR silent in form of dehydrated state on account of a pseudo Jahn-Teller effect. CuOx clusters always remain EPR inactive owing to antiferromagnetic effects, it is proposed that framework disruption after hydrothermal treatment is attributed to zeolite dealumination and the formation of CuOx clusters. CuOx formation becomes inevitable with Cu loadings surpassing the maximum isolated Cu2+ storage after harsh hydrothermal treatment for Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts. In the earlier work by Kim et al. [196], under severe aging condition, the Cu2+ ions located in the CHA cage agglomerated more readily than that in D6R sites, resulting in the formation of CuOx, whose growth might eventually disrupt the crystal structure of the SSZ-13 zeolite. After harsh hydrothermal treatment, Song et al. [51] discovered that [Cu(OH)]+-Z were susceptible to H2O attack and formed a mobile Cu(OH)2 species, and then migrated and agglomerated, eventually segregated from framework to form CuOx clusters. After harsh hydrothermal aging treatment, Han et al. [27] found that the phase transformation of isolated Cu2+ (both in D6R and CHA cage) agglomerated into CuxO (e.g., CuO and/or Cu2O), especially the high Cu/Al-ratio catalysts, leading to deactivation of Cu/SSZ-13. 5.2 Hydrothermal deactivation mechanism over Cu/SPO-34 Based on previous stability studies [197], Cu/SAPO-34 with an optimal copper loading has shown better hydrothermal stability than Cu/SSZ-13 even at 950 °C. Nevertheless, commercialized Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts have suffered quite unimaginable and perplexing failure and gradually retreated from the market owing to the low temperature (<100 °C) deactivation in the presence of moisture, therefore, compared with the high temperature hydrothermal deactivation [198], it is more urgent to clearly understand its low temperature failure. The root cause for Cu/SAPO-34 deactivation under humid conditions is the attack of framework atoms, which is similar to that of SAPO-34 zeolite. It has been documented that the SDAs significant influence Si distribution and framework charge density [48]. As proposed by Gao et al. [47], two causes were responsible for the irreversible hydrolysis for the SAPO-34, the first was that higher SiOAl bond density attacked by water molecules underwent irreversible hydrolysis more readily, the second was that the more CHA framework stress hydrolyzed more readily. This was particularly noteworthy for catalysts synthesized from MOR (instead of TEA and TEAOH), as illustrated in Fig. 10(b). [199]. Furthermore, the results from Woo et al. [48,199] showed that both irreversible Si condensation in the zeolite and Cu occupied less accessible sites and/or generation of CuOx clusters accounted for the low temperature deactivation mechanism of Cu/SAPO-34, the formation of Si clusters sterically hindered the mobility of the intermediate [Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+, which was again confirmed to be the rate-limiting step for the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperature in Cu/CHA. In addition, Leistner et al. [200] found the dominating deactivation mechanism was attributed to the decrease of active Cu sites rather than the breakage of the crystalline SAPO-34 framework. From above discussions, the intrinsic structural complexity of Cu/SAPO-34 renders the root causes are difficult to identify, thus Wang et al. [49] designed model Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts and proposed the following catalyst deactivation steps: (1) [Cu(OH)]+ hydrolysis into mobile Cu(OH)2 moieties, (2) the generation of terminal ≡Al-OH/≡Al(H2O)n, and (3) interactions between Cu(OH)2 and above terminal Al, generating Cu-aluminate like species. The authors suggested that preventing the ≡Si-O(H)-Al≡ and [Cu(OH)]+ sites from hydrolysis could be realized by flushing the SCR catalyst bed with NH3. In a word, the hydrothermal durability of Cu/SAPO-34 is largely affected by Si distribution and SDA. 5.3 Promotion of Cu/SSZ-13 high-temperature hydrothermal stability For Cu/SSZ-13, how to balance high-temperature hydrothermal stability and the low-temperature SCR activity has puzzled scientists for a long time, to be specific, (1) [Cu(OH)]+-Z active sites display a little higher turn-over frequency but lower hydrothermal stability than Cu2+-2Z, the former is discovered to convert readily to CuOx clusters after high hydrothermal treatment. (2) a dominant Cu2+-2Z situation always comes from low Si/Al ratios substrates, however, which unavoidably results in fairly high residual Brønsted acid sites that are prone to hydrolysis and undergo dealumination, however, provided Cu/Al ratios are carefully controlled and optimized, the nature and location of Cu ions are elaborately regulated and the synthetic methods are technically improved, the Al-rich Cu/SSZ-13 (e.g., Si/Al = 4–6) catalysts should also present satisfactory hydrothermal stability. All things considered, it is expected to maximize Cu2+-2Z and minimize [Cu(OH)]+-Z, which is of greatest benefit for the promotion of long-term stability [52]. Note that Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts with Si/Al ratios less than 6 have not yet been accepted for in real-word NH3-SCR, which is the goal and direction of our research. Promoting hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 is to protect the stabilities of active Cu ions and zeolitic framework. To avoid the formation of CuOx clusters and dealumination, two tactics, largely unexplored, are suggested here to enhance the hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13: (1) incorporation of metal additives to effectively stabilizes the framework or/and restrain the formation of CuOx clusters. (2) introduction of certain amount alkali cocations to neutralize Brønsted acid sites, which protects the aluminum sites against water molecules attack and acts as Lewis acids. 5.3.1 Incorporation of metal additives The approach of introducing rare-earth (RE) elements such as Ce and yttrium (Y) holds promise for increasing the hydrothermal stability of zeolites. Wang et al. [201] reported cerium-stabilized Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts, where Ce exchange stabilized the Cu active center, partially prevented dealumination of the SSZ-13 framework, in another optimized Ce modified Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts designed by Usui et al. [202], where Ce could fill the ion-exchange sites and stabilizes the framework, resulting in enhanced hydrothermal stability. Zhao et al. [203] also found the 6MRs were preferentially occupied by Cu2+ ions owing to the addition of Y ions, which kept the active centers in the Al-rich Cu/SSZ-13. More recently, a dual-metal Cu&Zn/SSZ-13 was first proposed by Xu et al. [204], experimental and DFT results indicated the obtained main [Cu-O-Zn]-Z and [Zn-O-Zn]-Z complexes were much more stable than the mono-Cu species ([Cu-OH]-Z) under hydrothermal aging, as illustrated in Fig. 11 (a), this work has expanded the possibility of more metal additives in higher hydrothermal stability. 5.3.2 Alkali metal co-cations modification From recent patents and open scientific literatures, with respect to the roles of alkali metal co-cations (especially Na+), three key points are summarized [195,205]: (1) repulsive interactions between alkali metal co-cations and Cu ions. (2) neutralizing Brønsted acid sites to prevent dealumination after hydrothermal treatment. (3) acting as Lewis acids for a beneficial NH3 adsorption function. Even so, the intrinsic roles of these co-cations, such as how they affect Cu location and distribution and how they keep the zeolite structure stable, have not yet been absolutely understood. Gao et al. [193] discovered that the addition of Na+ and Li+ could suppress dealumination and enhance low temperature NOx conversion over low-Cu loaded Cu/SSZ-13. Zhao et al. [206] also proved that moderate Na+ content can preserve most TFAl in Al-rich SSZ-13 zeolites (Si/Al = 4), whereas excess amount of Na+ weaken the interaction between active Cu ions and zeolite framework, which was detrimental to high temperature stabilities. The results are also consistent with Cui et al. [195], who conducted comprehensive investigations to clarify the interaction between Cu and co-cation (Na+ and K+) on atomic level, that is, repulsive interactions between alkali metal co-cations and separate Cu ions precluded the possibility that one Cu ion can coexist with more than one co-cation in one hexagonal unit cell, thus, the Cu2+ ions preferentially occupied 6MRs and co-cations preferentially occupied 8MRs, in addition, the co-cations of Ca2+ destabilizing isolated Cu ions failed to demonstrate any beneficial effects. Apart from these publications, new strategies to promote the hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 consist of but not limited regulating and optimizing the distribution of the TFAl assisted by the SAPO-34 seed [207], dry gel conversion with high crystallite [208], adjusting morphology and particle size [209–211], designing core-shell structure [212], and scavenging undesired CuOx by high ZrO2 dispersion [213]. Nevertheless, the more effective strategies involved in higher hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 is still a pendent issue for further research. 5.4 Promotion of Cu/SAPO-34 low-temperature hydrothermal stability Getting insight into the low-temperature deactivation mechanism of Cu/SAPO-34 is crucially important for industrialized application, but how to protect the framework and regenerate the deactivated Cu/SAPO-34 makes more sense. Base on the previous discussions in Section 5.2, we could propose that promoting low-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu/SAPO-34 is to protect SiOAl bond and inhibit irreversible Si condensation. Wang et al. [64] observed the isolated Cu2+ ions acted as not only the active centers and but also a structural stabilizing agent, which prevented SiOAl bonds from H2O molecules attack. NH3 pre-saturation may help inhibit the transformation of Si(4OAl) species to Si islands during the hydration treatment, similar conclusion was obtained by Wang et al. [49], where NH3 molecule bound more strongly with isolated Cu2+ ions than H2O, thus inhibiting the hydrolysis reaction. For regenerating the deactivated Cu/SAPO-34, efforts are currently underway by Woo et al. [214,215], as presented in Fig. 11(b). Interestingly and surprisingly, they found that 10 % H2O could dissociate Si clusters induced by Si condensation exposure to 5 or 7.5 % H2O of SAPO-34 (MOR as SDA) and converted them back to form SiOH bonds, thus recovering the mobility of the linear [Cu-(NH3)2]+ complex, apart from this contribution, they also found the framework Si species Si(4OAl), Si(3OAl) hydrolyzed into (Si-O-)2Si(-OH)2, (Si-O-)3Si-OH, respectively, being no different, leading to the generation of Si clusters through Si condensation, however, with the temperature increasing, acetic acid could also dissociate the formed Si clusters, rendering them to go back to the SAPO-34 crystalline through reverse hydrolysis process. 6 Summary and outlook In the past several years, remarkable advances, achieved in understanding of Cu/CHA catalysts on atomic and molecular levels and their catalytic nature in NH3-SCR reaction, paved the way for better exploiting and designing the next generation of novel and efficient materials. Nevertheless, there are still many challenges to be addressed owing to the complexity of the actual operating conditions, especially industrial production and the catalyst deactivation, thus the comprehensive strategies are needed to overcome the particular thresholds. This review concentrates on the recent research progress on zeolite synthesis, SCR reaction mechanisms, sulfur/alkali (alkaline) metal/phosphorus poisoning mechanisms and hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms as well as the corresponding poisoning-resistant and protective strategies, making it closer to practical industrial applications. Herein, several key insights are briefly summarized below: For Cu/SSZ-13, distribution of Al atoms is largely dependent on SDA, Na+ loading and solvent medium, it is now clear that Cu2+-2Z sites balanced by paired Al provide stronger stabilization than [Cu(OH)]+-Z sites balanced by isolated Al. It is expected to maximize Cu2+-2Z and minimize [Cu(OH)]+-Z, because Cu2+-2Z sites are more resistant than [Cu(OH)]+-Z in sulfur poisoning, phosphorus poisoning and hydrothermal aging. For Cu/SAPO-34, the Si distribution in the framework is also affected by different SDAs, more Si (nOAl, n = 1–4) rather than Si(0OAl) structures may be in favor of the catalytic performance of NH3-SCR, however, low-temperature hydrothermal deactivation problems should be considered simultaneously. Ultrafast and continuous flow is beneficial for large scale production, but the kinetics, the thermodynamics and the hydrodynamics could not be considered separately. In the future, more extensive endeavor should be devoted to the sustainable synthesis of zeolites, such as organotemplate-free synthesis and solvent-free synthesis routes. At low temperatures between 150 °C and 250 °C, Cu ions are solvated by NH3 and become dynamic, which no longer belongs to the scope of a heterogeneous catalyst, but could be considered a quasi-homogeneous reaction system. At temperatures between 250 °C and 350 °C, the observed “seagull” dip could be explained by the [Cu(NH3)2]+ complexes are not stable with increasing temperature and the Cu ions lose their mobility. Once temperatures above ∼350 °C, the Cu ions lose NH3 solvation and find the anchor sites in the zeolite lattice where they become monomeric and heterogeneous. More advanced characterization tools and molecular-scale computational models are needed to capture comprehensive and solid information in the future. In the matter of sulfur/alkali (alkaline) metal/phosphorus poisoning mechanisms and hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms, both copper active sites and the zeolite framework are easily disrupted, thus the Cu2+ ↔ Cu+ redox cycle cannot be achieved, the corresponding protective strategies are also mainly built around these two points. More effort must be spent on studying the co-effects of poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation in the future. We should keep in mind that the commercial Cu/CHA SCR catalysts are not sufficiently active for cold-start NOx emissions, inclusion of a PNA (e.g., Pd-containing CHA or MFI) as a new module in existing emission-control system appear more promising, however, challenges remain with complex trapping conditions (e.g., repeated cold starts, the presence of other exhaust species such as CO2, H2O, CO and hydrocarbons, sulfur poisoning and hydrothermal aging deactivation), in the meantime, do not forget to explore other novel type zeolites (AEI, LTA, RTH, KFI, etc.) and remember that there is room for improvement before 100 % NOx removal efficiency. coredata.dc:description: Copper-exchanged SSZ-13 and SAPO-34 (Cu/CHA) zeolites catalysts have been commercially utilized for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx by NH3. Despite the significant advances in both fundamental research and industrial application have been made, the limited catalytic activity at low exhaust temperatures, the challenges of sulfur/alkali (alkaline) metal/phosphorus poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation have spurred the development of new generation NH3-SCR catalysts. This paper reviews the recent progress for Cu/CHA in regard to zeolite synthesis, the latest SCR reaction mechanisms, the poisoning and hydrothermal deactivation mechanisms, more importantly, corresponding poisoning-resistant and protective strategies are also proposed, some issues that still need to be addressed are also highlighted. We hope to construct a linkage between next generation of catalysts and real-world applicable demands to meet the escalating emission regulations in the near future.
